There is no conclusive evidence that IUDs prevent implantation! Hormonal IUDs prevent ovulation and Copper IUDs kill sperm; it's suspected that the latter MIGHT affect implantation, but we don't know. Please don't perpetuate misconceptions that often lead to bad policies and social attitudes that hurt women.

Again, thank you for talking about the science of sex. There are any number of great sex ed/sexual behavior channels, but none that I've found, Sexplanations included, that give any indepth information as to what's happening biologically. And I think it's of utmost importance for us as biological beings to know and understand this material even before getting into the behavioral and physiological parts of the equation.
Don't get me wrong, Sexplanations is great, but I regularly find myself saying, "yeah, but you didn't actually tell me anything. Certainly not anything about the physiology of (sexy whatever topic).”
So, yes, thank you CrashCourse for getting to the real nitty gritty of what we do in the bedroom in a way that no one else is talking about. :D

For people who want to know about all the things this episode will NOT be talking about, I suggest you visit Sexplanations, which is an educational Youtube channel produced by Hank Green, with Dr Lindsey Doe, a clinical sexologist, as host. Crash Course A&P will give you the fascinating biological info, Sexplanations has videos to answer all your sex related questions, and if it doesn't, you can leave a comment on their channel and Dr Doe will see if she can do a video on it.

DFTBA and keep up the love for learning!

P.S: While Sexplanations is a purely educational channel, it does go into quite a lot of sexual detail and occasionally uses colloquial terms for genitalia so it may or may not be SFW, depending on how strict you are.

the path to a baby is basically and iron wall. First consent, then waiting for the right time of the month, then sperm need to go through the ridiculously difficult gauntlet of the female reproductive system, and then the zygote has to make it to the uterus, and then it takes 8-9 months before the baby is done, during which time multiple things could cause miscarriage. Baby making is difficult.
